description: EC-Council's Ethical Hacking and Countermeasures (CEH) covers concepts and tools related to exploiting systems, networks, devices and operating platforms. This includes hacking concepts such as vulnerability assessment, network intrusion, reverse engineering, defacing websites, damaging network appliances, launching distributed denial-of-service attacks, massive worm propagation, breaking passwords, brute-forcing authentication systems, cracking encryption, exploiting systems, advance viruses, Trojans, and other malware. This certificate is targeted at site administrators, security professionals, auditors and anyone who is concerned about the integrity of the network infrastructure.

00:28:55.661 --> 00:28:58.387
The next phase can be part of
the same activity chain or

585
00:28:58.387 --> 00:29:00.250
can be distinctly different.

586
00:29:00.250 --> 00:29:04.390
When they choose to get in once and that's
it, or may wanna get in and stay there and

587
00:29:04.390 --> 00:29:05.839
maintain access long term.

588
00:29:05.839 --> 00:29:10.550
Maintaining access is all about keeping
control, keeping open that pipe that we'd

589
00:29:10.550 --> 00:29:14.170
broken open into the system
by finding a vulnerability.

590
00:29:14.170 --> 00:29:16.940
So it's one thing to get in,
it's another thing to stay there,

591
00:29:16.940 --> 00:29:18.338
we may put keyloggers in place.

592
00:29:18.338 --> 00:29:22.806
We may put in remote access
trojans like I mentioned,

593
00:29:22.806 --> 00:29:28.580
RATS and/or some sort of root kit or
zombie-type system software.

594
00:29:28.580 --> 00:29:32.414
That can be put there to maintain
control over that box on demand and

595
00:29:32.414 --> 00:29:35.427
then wake it up and
grab it when we need it, and then,

596
00:29:35.427 --> 00:29:38.386
obviously, over time be
able to profit from that.

597
00:29:38.386 --> 00:29:43.498
And then finally, clearing tracks is all
about removing evidence of what we did,

598
00:29:43.498 --> 00:29:47.260
we may go in and
we may decide to delete log files, right?

599
00:29:47.260 --> 00:29:50.963
We may go in and hide the malicious
activities we've been involved with,

600
00:29:50.963 --> 00:29:53.544
we may wanna cover up
continuing access over time.

601
00:29:53.544 --> 00:29:57.756
We may wanna be able to get rid of
suspicious information that was left

602
00:29:57.756 --> 00:30:02.790
there, install files, things like that,

603
00:30:02.790 --> 00:30:05.848
We're always gonna try, if we're smart,

604
00:30:05.848 --> 00:30:08.640
try to prevent the people that
are gonna come and forensically

605
00:30:08.640 --> 00:30:12.202
examine the system when we're done with
it, from finding what we're doing.

606
00:30:12.202 --> 00:30:15.296
So we wanna cover up those tracks,
if possible,

607
00:30:15.296 --> 00:30:19.640
we may have software we use to
remove evidence of our activities.

608
00:30:19.640 --> 00:30:22.506
We may decide to uninstall
certain software,

609
00:30:22.506 --> 00:30:25.084
we may decide to create fake log entries.

610
00:30:25.084 --> 00:30:28.835
We may decide to blow up the system,

00:30:28.835 --> 00:30:31.030
all evidence of what we did.

612
00:30:31.030 --> 00:30:34.685
If it's a router, we may decide to
modify the running config of the system,

613
00:30:34.685 --> 00:30:37.380
leaving behind no evidence
when we restart the router.

614
00:30:37.380 --> 00:30:40.675
Except the fact that it was restarted

615
00:30:40.675 --> 00:30:43.237
it'll be loaded from the stored config,
and therefore,

616
00:30:43.237 --> 00:30:45.100
the modifications will disappear.

617
00:30:45.100 --> 00:30:48.007
There's lots of ways we can hack in,
do a bunch of stuff, and

618
00:30:48.007 --> 00:30:49.946

619
00:30:49.946 --> 00:30:53.383

00:30:53.383 --> 00:30:56.480

you never know they were there.

621
00:30:56.480 --> 00:30:59.742
Because they're so good at what they do,

00:30:59.742 --> 00:31:02.630
that you have no idea that they've

00:31:02.630 --> 00:31:06.303
Hacking, whether you're doing it

00:31:06.303 --> 00:31:09.790

00:31:09.790 --> 00:31:13.210

00:31:13.210 --> 00:31:17.001

I mean they may be good, don't get me

639
00:31:52.618 --> 00:31:54.460
you just have to be good.

00:31:54.460 --> 00:31:58.119

So we thank you for that, some great,

episodes.description: In this episode, Adam and Mike begin phase three of the attack lifecycle, enumeration. They look at using tools like NBTStat and Netstat to enumerate open ports and established connections. They also look at tools like Task Manager, and the PS suite, to list running processes.

59
00:02:50.280 --> 00:02:55.630

60

61

65

66
00:03:20.010 --> 00:03:22.450

take over and do other things.

67
00:03:22.450 --> 00:03:26.280
So as a category, all the stuff we're
talking about here is considered or

The Trojan horse, kinda classic example,

70

The idea here, as we talk about

75

something.

76
00:03:55.640 --> 00:03:59.230
What actually then happens is you probably

77
00:03:59.230 --> 00:04:02.610
if you will, right, the package

78
00:04:02.610 --> 00:04:06.000
But inside of that, you're then
gonna get a nasty surprise, right,

79
00:04:06.000 --> 00:04:08.252
something else that we

80
00:04:08.252 --> 00:04:13.044
Which is gonna be this piece of software
that will allow an attacker to either get

81

82

We often talk about remote access Trojans,

83

85

86
00:04:34.170 --> 00:04:39.820
Allow them to take over the machine and
either zombie it or botify it.

87
00:04:39.820 --> 00:04:42.220
We talk about different
concepts generically, right?

88
00:04:42.220 --> 00:04:43.800
Gone are the days where we just say, yes,

00:04:52.500 --> 00:04:55.360

94
00:04:55.360 --> 00:04:59.990

95
00:04:59.990 --> 00:05:02.350
These are all examples of Trojan horses.

96

00:05:05.982 --> 00:05:09.595

99
00:05:09.595 --> 00:05:11.660
to use the language of security,

100
00:05:11.660 --> 00:05:16.602
we often talk about something that is
a communication pathway that is unknown,

101
00:05:16.602 --> 00:05:22.080
unlooked for, unrecognized by us, right,
as we scan and we look at the machine.

102
00:05:22.080 --> 00:05:25.840
And it allows us to bypass the normal
authentication, areas of a system or

103
00:05:25.840 --> 00:05:27.740
normal processes in the system.

104
00:05:27.740 --> 00:05:31.290
So that we can use the system

105
00:05:31.290 --> 00:05:34.210
without the authentication
mechanisms normally that are there,

106
00:05:34.210 --> 00:05:35.655
stopping us as a bad actor.

107
00:05:35.655 --> 00:05:39.570
Backdoors are often the result of
a system being Trojaned where we

00:08:40.120 --> 00:08:41.920

00:08:44.301 --> 00:08:46.798

00:08:46.798 --> 00:08:47.575
So root kits.

178
00:08:47.575 --> 00:08:50.525
These are pieces of software again,
in the malware category.

179
00:08:50.525 --> 00:08:53.425
Loaded, a lot of times,
delivered through a trojan horse.

180
00:08:53.425 --> 00:08:57.555
Delivered as a payload in another,
malware attack of some kind.

00:08:57.555 --> 00:08:59.730
Left in the system, burrowing deep,

00:08:59.730 --> 00:09:03.760

specialized software that will detect it.

183
00:09:03.760 --> 00:09:07.290
We often find a lot of root kit

00:09:07.290 --> 00:09:10.920

have to use to disinfect a system.

00:09:10.920 --> 00:09:15.740

control, hence the name root kit.

186
00:09:15.740 --> 00:09:16.448
Root, control.

187
00:09:16.448 --> 00:09:19.968
To be given to the bad actor,
who can then use it against the machine.

00:09:19.968 --> 00:09:21.959

191

00:09:32.578 --> 00:09:35.040

00:09:35.040 --> 00:09:35.910
Same idea.

194
00:09:35.910 --> 00:09:37.500
The challenge is, you have to be careful.

195
00:09:37.500 --> 00:09:41.960

these operating system image files, and

00:09:41.960 --> 00:09:46.600
when you do that, what's gonna happen is,
and my mouse stopped working, there we go.

197
00:09:46.600 --> 00:09:50.180

00:09:53.281 --> 00:09:57.300
What will happen with
that is ultimately that

00:09:57.300 --> 00:10:01.130

00:10:01.130 --> 00:10:03.570

jailbreak it, and

202
00:10:03.570 --> 00:10:06.170

203
00:10:06.170 --> 00:10:09.020

204
00:10:09.020 --> 00:10:10.910
So, you gotta be really
careful with this stuff.

MobiStealth rather.

So there's all these different
ones out there that we may see.

So I was thinking about that.

1020

We were talking about the mobile
device management platforms.

1021

Why they're so important,
there's a million of them out there.

1022

I mean there are so many.

AirWatch is one of the most popular

Right?
But there's XenMobile.

Xen has a real good platform from Citrix.

1026
00:48:25.225 --> 00:48:26.410
That's one of their specialties.

1027
00:48:26.410 --> 00:48:28.700
There's Mobile Iron,
there's a whole bunch of different ones.

1028
00:48:28.700 --> 00:48:32.750
Whatever you use I can't say
enough about MDM and why it is so

1029
00:48:32.750 --> 00:48:35.757
important in an episode like this, right?

1030
00:48:35.757 --> 00:48:40.050
The whole BYOD phenomenon has

1031
00:48:40.050 --> 00:48:42.610
I think now corporate entities
have given up and just said, hey,

1032
00:48:42.610 --> 00:48:44.330
we're not in the phone business anymore.

1033
00:48:44.330 --> 00:48:45.454
Bring your own phone in.

1034

We're gonna apply management
at the perimeter and

1035

1036

But we're not gonna really deal

1037
00:48:54.370 --> 00:48:57.730
you being given corporate advice and
trying to do that whole thing.

1038
00:48:57.730 --> 00:48:59.555
It just really was so ineffective, right?

1039
00:48:59.555 --> 00:49:00.870
>> Mm-hm.
>> I mean they were in the hardware

1040
00:49:00.870 --> 00:49:03.670
business and the software business and
it was just very difficult to manage.

1041
00:49:03.670 --> 00:49:06.285
And it was really just counterproductive.

1042
00:49:06.285 --> 00:49:09.975
So most of my customers have gotten
out of that whole thought process.

1043
00:49:09.975 --> 00:49:12.425
And I think for the betterment
of the organization [LAUGH] and

1044
00:49:12.425 --> 00:49:14.155
the sanity of the individuals as well.

1045
00:49:14.155 --> 00:49:16.155
So jst thinking about that kind of stuff.

1046
00:49:16.155 --> 00:49:19.365
But probably as we talk about this and
thinking about

1047
00:49:19.365 --> 00:49:23.315
just mobile device management overall and
hacking on mobile platforms.

1048
00:49:23.315 --> 00:49:27.540
It's the basic thought process around
security 101 stuff that we do.

1049
00:49:27.540 --> 00:49:31.550
Encouraging users to use strong passwords,
applying encryption locally on the device.

1050
00:49:31.550 --> 00:49:33.730
Making sure they don't leave
the device unsecured and

1051
00:49:33.730 --> 00:49:35.500
unprotected if they walk away.

1052
00:49:35.500 --> 00:49:38.840
Using some sort of a password or
a PIN or whatever it may be.

1053
00:49:38.840 --> 00:49:41.950
Making sure that they only
apply vendor approved patches.

1054
00:49:41.950 --> 00:49:45.980
They only apply digitally signed and
validated applications.

1055
00:49:45.980 --> 00:49:48.020
If we can get users just to do that stuff,

1056
00:49:48.020 --> 00:49:50.130
I mean most of the problems
we have in this area go away.

1057
00:49:50.130 --> 00:49:51.090
Believe it or not, it's true.

1058
00:49:51.090 --> 00:49:51.660
It's hard.

1059
00:49:51.660 --> 00:49:52.500
I'm not saying that's easy.

1060
00:49:52.500 --> 00:49:55.340
But i'm just pointing out that

1061
00:49:55.340 --> 00:49:57.237
That or we go back to coconut.

1062

>> It's coco-walk as opposed to

coconut, right?

1067

1068

1069

1070

A lot of information about

1071

looking at the world of

1072

We started off looking at

1074

1075

So we appreciate that.

1076

1077

episodes.description: In this episode, Adam and Mike talk about intrusion detection and intrusion prevention systems, how they work and where they are placed in our network. They look at the methods these systems use to detect attacks. Then they discuss firewalls, comparing stateful and stateless firewalls.
episodes.title: IDS, Firewalls and Honeypots
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1

[MUSIC]

2

Hello, welcome to another

4

today we're doing our
Certified Ethical Hacker version 9.

5

And specifically in this episode, we're
going to be looking at intrusion detection

6
00:00:24.750 --> 00:00:30.140
and intrusion prevention systems,
firewalls, hand puppets, and honey pots.

7

And here to help us with all of the above
is Mr Adam Gordon, how are you doing Adam?

8

9

10
00:00:36.965 --> 00:00:38.850
>> [LAUGH]
>> I'm doing good.

11
00:00:38.850 --> 00:00:43.210
So, we're gonna talk a little bit about
as Mike was just saying, IDSs, IPSs,

12
00:00:43.210 --> 00:00:48.095
Honeypots, Firewalls,
Honeynets, black coffee in bed.

13
00:00:48.095 --> 00:00:52.005
Great band, Squeeze,
from the 1980s, by the way, 1990s.

14
00:00:52.005 --> 00:00:57.505
And we are going to start that discussion
by actually taking a quick look

15
00:00:57.505 --> 00:01:01.810
at a drawing that Mike has
been laboring over here.

16
00:01:01.810 --> 00:01:05.313
And I noticed the color scheme is as

17
00:01:05.313 --> 00:01:07.500
>> [LAUGH] You can tell I did this,

18

>> Yes, I see our conversation stuck and

19

20

And I notice that even worse is
the fact that the border around

21
00:01:16.822 --> 00:01:20.640
the drawing on the desktop
is actually colorful.

22
00:01:20.640 --> 00:01:21.280
>> Yes.
[LAUGH]

23
00:01:21.280 --> 00:01:22.563
>> So we do have color, but

24
00:01:22.563 --> 00:01:25.719
it's not making it's way into

25
00:01:25.719 --> 00:01:26.945
>> It's not, it's not.

26
00:01:26.945 --> 00:01:30.320
>> Okay so now that we've harped
on that enough let us continue.

27
00:01:30.320 --> 00:01:34.980
So what we thought we would do
quickly is just remind ourselves

28
00:01:34.980 --> 00:01:39.480
of what an IDS and/or IPS thought process
looks like from two perspectives.

29
00:01:39.480 --> 00:01:42.495
One we'll talk through the narrative
around what it is, how it works,

30
00:01:42.495 --> 00:01:44.768
why it does what it does,
but also how we deploy them.

31
00:01:44.768 --> 00:01:47.760
Very important to understand that
we have some options here, right?

32
00:01:47.760 --> 00:01:51.150
We have a network-based option and
we have a host based option.

33
00:01:51.150 --> 00:01:53.590
So we just wanted to quickly
throw together a diagram.

34
00:01:53.590 --> 00:01:56.911
We've got a little DMZ going on
there in between the two firewalls,

35
00:01:56.911 --> 00:01:58.082
got a web server there.

36
00:01:58.082 --> 00:01:59.847
And then we're gonna
totally ignore that for

37
00:01:59.847 --> 00:02:03.270
the rest of the conversation cuz it has
absolutely no bearing on what we're doing.

38
00:02:03.270 --> 00:02:07.140
So it's there but it's like a distraction,
it's actually not supposed to be there.

39
00:02:07.140 --> 00:02:11.246
And then on the inside on
the LAN we have an IDS/IPS

40
00:02:11.246 --> 00:02:15.500
device in line as we would say
which is a network deployment.

41
00:02:15.500 --> 00:02:17.940
So we call that a NID,
a network-based ideas or

42
00:02:17.940 --> 00:02:21.140
a NIP, a network-based IPS deployment.

43
00:02:21.140 --> 00:02:25.800
And the network-based discussion is
really about putting a device in

44
00:02:25.800 --> 00:02:28.670
that will a lot of times
be attached to a switch.

45
00:02:28.670 --> 00:02:31.420
It may not actually be sitting in line,
although it can be.

46
00:02:31.420 --> 00:02:35.570
We talked, in the sniffing episodes, a
little bit about the idea of being able to

47
00:02:35.570 --> 00:02:40.240
use a SPAN port, right, and being able to,
essentially, monitor through the switch.

48
00:02:40.240 --> 00:02:43.500
And the value of doing that would be
that we get all the traffic through

49
00:02:43.500 --> 00:02:45.170
that switch on that subnet.

50
00:02:45.170 --> 00:02:48.490
We could simply plug this in
directly to the network as well.

51
00:02:48.490 --> 00:02:50.930
There's different ways when they deploy,
so it would depend on the architecture.

52
00:02:50.930 --> 00:02:53.840
But traditionally,
we will run that through a switch, and

53
00:02:53.840 --> 00:02:58.990
then on an individual machine,
some sort of a server there, a SQL Server.

54
00:02:58.990 --> 00:03:04.870
We have an IDS/IPS box representing
an agent that would be running inside

55
00:03:04.870 --> 00:03:09.030
of the systems, this would be the host
base, the HID or the HIP based deployment.

56
00:03:09.030 --> 00:03:13.380
So host based IDS, host based IPS where
we have a piece of software essentially

57
00:03:13.380 --> 00:03:17.690
running on the system and then allowing
us to monitor traffic coming in and

58
00:03:17.690 --> 00:03:21.320
going out of this box, but
limited to this particular box.

59
00:03:21.320 --> 00:03:23.435
As opposed to the broader conversation and

60
00:03:23.435 --> 00:03:26.520
broader information gathering of
network based appliance of device.

61
00:03:26.520 --> 00:03:28.750
So I just wanna have a sense of that.

62
00:03:28.750 --> 00:03:31.930
We're also wanna talk a bit
about what IDS is and IPS do.

63
00:03:31.930 --> 00:03:33.979
There are some subtle, but
very important differences between them.

64
00:03:33.979 --> 00:03:39.515
The main difference between these two
devices is that it is a question of focus.

65
00:03:39.515 --> 00:03:42.860
I think it's probably a good way of
thinking about it in a question of

66
00:03:42.860 --> 00:03:43.710
purpose.

67
00:03:43.710 --> 00:03:47.580
So IDSs are passive devices,
they will monitor and alert us.

68
00:03:47.580 --> 00:03:50.984
And I often make this point
when I talk about this, and

69
00:03:50.984 --> 00:03:54.691
I know I've made this point in
some of our other episodes,

70
00:03:54.691 --> 00:03:59.686
that IDS's even though we consider them
passive, do have the ability to alert

71
00:03:59.686 --> 00:04:03.186
us to the fact that we are able
to see traffic coming in.

72
00:04:03.186 --> 00:04:07.870
Maybe let's from the DMZ coming across
through the web server, hypothetically.

73
00:04:07.870 --> 00:04:11.740
We would see traffic coming across and
we're able to then be

74
00:04:11.740 --> 00:04:16.310
monitoring in real time but also alert
ourselves that there may be a problem.

75
00:04:16.310 --> 00:04:19.170
Maybe there is some sort of packet or

76
00:04:19.170 --> 00:04:22.150
some sort of group of
packets that look unusual.

77
00:04:22.150 --> 00:04:25.330
So we can be alerted and
that is not an activity or

78
00:04:25.330 --> 00:04:28.370
an action that is considered
to be necessary for

79
00:04:28.370 --> 00:04:31.770
the ideas to undertake other than
simply to pass along information.

80
00:04:31.770 --> 00:04:34.900
So we still consider this to
be passive with an IPS of

81
00:04:34.900 --> 00:04:37.540
intrusion prevention systems,
these are active systems.

82
00:04:37.540 --> 00:04:39.620
They do everything IDSs do, but

83
00:04:39.620 --> 00:04:43.857
they in addition can take on
the added burden, added liability,

84
00:04:43.857 --> 00:04:49.327
and/or added responsibility of being able
to take action to change or modify system

85
00:04:49.327 --> 00:04:54.899
behavior as a result of inbound traffic
end notification, a potential compromise.

86
00:04:54.899 --> 00:04:59.007
So they may trigger an entry in
the firewall to change a block or route,

87
00:04:59.007 --> 00:05:03.055
they may add or remove an application
from a white or a black list.

88
00:05:03.055 --> 00:05:06.297
They may do a variety of things
that require additional effort and

89
00:05:06.297 --> 00:05:07.737
capability to achieve.

90
00:05:07.737 --> 00:05:10.777
And so
IPS's are going to be able to take on

91
00:05:10.777 --> 00:05:13.247
the ability to be able to
change our network on the fly.

92
00:05:13.247 --> 00:05:16.537
Which is also very important for
us to think about and to consider.

93
00:05:16.537 --> 00:05:18.097
So just a little way to get started here.

94
00:05:18.097 --> 00:05:21.357
A little graphic that allows
us to show this to you.

95
00:05:21.357 --> 00:05:24.817
I notice as we're looking at the graphic
that you've stopped signing your work.

96
00:05:24.817 --> 00:05:26.829
>> No.
>> Which is not the way you want to

97
00:05:26.829 --> 00:05:27.623
get famous.

98
00:05:27.623 --> 00:05:28.837
>> No, it's not.
>> Because nobody knows who it is.

99
00:05:28.837 --> 00:05:31.718
Because I'm going to tell everybody
that Meagan did that, if you don't sign,

100
00:05:31.718 --> 00:05:33.274
it just that they think that, there we go.

101
00:05:33.274 --> 00:05:34.454
Yeah, you can't see it, but okay.

102
00:05:34.454 --> 00:05:36.733
>> [LAUGH]
>> You know how to put the squiggly under

103
00:05:36.733 --> 00:05:39.255
there so it looks like a half smiley,
but that's your blue,

104
00:05:39.255 --> 00:05:42.432
I guess it's not your blue period it's
your black period, so that's why.

105
00:05:42.432 --> 00:05:46.966
Later historians and art critics
will notice there was a change in

106
00:05:46.966 --> 00:05:50.690
MIke's demeanor during
this period in time.

107
00:05:50.690 --> 00:05:53.660
All right so we have that diagram and
so thank you very much for

108
00:05:53.660 --> 00:05:54.850
taking care of that for us.

109
00:05:54.850 --> 00:05:55.890
We do appreciate that.

110
00:05:55.890 --> 00:05:58.165
So when we think about IDSs and

111
00:05:58.165 --> 00:06:02.080
IPSs one of the very first things you
want to consider is placement, right?

112
00:06:02.080 --> 00:06:03.280
I mean placement is key.

113
00:06:03.280 --> 00:06:07.180
We have to understand where the device is
in relation to the traffic that we want to

114
00:06:07.180 --> 00:06:07.930
monitor.

115
00:06:07.930 --> 00:06:11.630
Because if we want to monitor broadly
across a subnet or portions of

116
00:06:11.630 --> 00:06:14.980
the network, doing a host-based deployment
is not going to get the job done.

117
00:06:14.980 --> 00:06:17.960
But if we want to monitor
a very specifically narrowly

118
00:06:17.960 --> 00:06:21.730
targeted information, we need to
be doing a host based employment.

119
00:06:21.730 --> 00:06:25.665
We could get that with a network-based IDS
but we'll have to allow more filtering.

120
00:06:25.665 --> 00:06:28.330
It will be a lot more difficult
to figure out how to zero in

121
00:06:28.330 --> 00:06:32.320
on that information in the larger sets or
volumes of data that we generate.

122
00:06:32.320 --> 00:06:34.480
>> Have you seen environments
where they might do both?

123
00:06:34.480 --> 00:06:38.590
One general to monitor the entire network
but then a particular server that's

124
00:06:38.590 --> 00:06:43.240
especially sensitive and run a host based
on that server as well as a network based?

125
00:06:43.240 --> 00:06:45.245
>> Absolutely yes,
it's a good point to make.

126
00:06:45.245 --> 00:06:47.115
We see a lot of that in many networks.

127
00:06:47.115 --> 00:06:50.025
We will do exactly what Mike described,
the two tier architecture,

128
00:06:50.025 --> 00:06:53.985
where we want the broad monitor,
broad application that a NID or

129
00:06:53.985 --> 00:06:57.030
NIP will provide to us in terms
of the network based portion.

130
00:06:57.030 --> 00:07:00.205
But we then want the specificity of
certain boxes that we can drill down on.

131
00:07:00.205 --> 00:07:05.115
And from an auditability perspective,
a compliance perspective perhaps,

132
00:07:05.115 --> 00:07:09.044
maybe a governance risk and
compliance consideration here,

133
00:07:09.044 --> 00:07:13.970
we want to be able to have tailored and
specific monitoring of a local system.

134
00:07:13.970 --> 00:07:16.590
So, we will add agent based
deployments to certain systems.

135
00:07:16.590 --> 00:07:19.010
A lot of times databases
will be covered that way.

136
00:07:19.010 --> 00:07:20.900
We may or
may not deal with web service that way.

137
00:07:20.900 --> 00:07:24.300
A lot of times we can do broad
monitoring because they sit in the DMZ.

138
00:07:24.300 --> 00:07:28.500
So, we made just simply do a network
base device there to watch that traffic

139
00:07:28.500 --> 00:07:31.140
because we don't tend to have
a lot of boxes in the DMZ.

140
00:07:31.140 --> 00:07:34.830
So a network based deployment although it
will capture three or four things will

141
00:07:34.830 --> 00:07:39.060
actually be able to very quickly and
easily zero in on the boxes in the DMZ.

142
00:07:39.060 --> 00:07:43.101
But behind the firewall in the LAN,
the internal portion of the DMZ,

143
00:07:43.101 --> 00:07:45.341
we do tend to do targeted monitoring.

144
00:07:45.341 --> 00:07:48.609
Mail service for instance,
database service certainly or

145
00:07:48.609 --> 00:07:53.064
perhaps domain controllers, so directory
services maybe monitored that way.

146
00:07:53.064 --> 00:07:56.243
And then,
we would have a broad coverage overall.

147
00:07:56.243 --> 00:07:59.158
Is that we can port all that data out
to a CiM system traditionally and

148
00:07:59.158 --> 00:08:01.832
do the analytics real time monitoring,
if you wanna do that.

149
00:08:01.832 --> 00:08:04.204
So, Something that you
may wanna think about.

150
00:08:04.204 --> 00:08:08.290
So, let's talk a little bit now that
we've talked about placement and

151
00:08:08.290 --> 00:08:10.400
just a general architecture.

152
00:08:10.400 --> 00:08:11.660
Ways we detect an intrusion.

153
00:08:11.660 --> 00:08:14.560
We have been talking about
network versus host based but

154
00:08:14.560 --> 00:08:17.300
we also talk about the different
ways in which we have this done.

155
00:08:17.300 --> 00:08:20.260
I believe we have a list that
we can go to quickly for that.

156
00:08:20.260 --> 00:08:22.000

So imagine we have a square, right?

And inside that square, or

In the case of DES,

68
00:03:14.622 --> 00:03:16.559
And we're gonna put 64

69

But we're gonna take eight bits out of

And so we're actually gonna

75

76

77

85

86

87
00:04:30.575 --> 00:04:35.370
And then we operate on those blocks

88
00:04:35.370 --> 00:04:37.950
And so when we go to encrypt or

89
00:04:37.950 --> 00:04:41.670
we do that in a block

90
00:04:41.670 --> 00:04:46.400
Or 64 bits, or 24 bits, or

91
00:04:46.400 --> 00:04:47.320
It doesn't matter.

92
00:04:47.320 --> 00:04:51.860
We may have a variable size in the block,

93
00:04:51.860 --> 00:04:55.550

94
00:04:55.550 --> 00:04:58.220

95
00:04:58.220 --> 00:05:00.630

96
00:05:00.630 --> 00:05:04.501
Let's say we're supposed to have

97
00:05:04.501 --> 00:05:05.320
What do we do?

98
00:05:05.320 --> 00:05:07.100
We have to do what's called padding,

99
00:05:07.100 --> 00:05:11.120
We have to add some bits in to bring the
block up to full size, because the only

100
00:05:11.120 --> 00:05:14.600

101
00:05:14.600 --> 00:05:18.730
So we have to pad certain blocks in
order to make sure they are full size.

102
00:05:18.730 --> 00:05:21.540
Padding is just randomly
adding garbage in.

103
00:05:21.540 --> 00:05:23.130
That is nonsensical.

104
00:05:23.130 --> 00:05:25.597
But is there is basically
packing material right?

105
00:05:25.597 --> 00:05:27.040
>> Right.
>> Think of like pouring peanuts into

106
00:05:27.040 --> 00:05:30.480

107
00:05:30.480 --> 00:05:31.350
That's what we're doing.

108
00:05:31.350 --> 00:05:34.180
So if a block is not fully formed,
we're padding it.

109
00:05:34.180 --> 00:05:40.070
Now, in a stream cipher we don't have to
worry about chunking the data into blocks.

110
00:05:40.070 --> 00:05:42.840
Rather, we operate on the bits as
they go through one at time and

111
00:05:42.840 --> 00:05:47.880
essentially continuously are encrypting or

112
00:05:47.880 --> 00:05:50.230
So a stream cipher works
on the thought process or

113
00:05:50.230 --> 00:05:54.020

114
00:05:54.020 --> 00:05:57.330
Whereas a block site works on

115

00:08:27.550 --> 00:08:31.060

00:08:31.060 --> 00:08:33.920

00:08:37.530 --> 00:08:40.060

00:08:40.060 --> 00:08:43.250

00:08:43.250 --> 00:08:45.010

184
00:08:45.010 --> 00:08:47.170
So you wanna make sure

00:08:47.170 --> 00:08:52.580

00:08:52.580 --> 00:08:56.030

187
00:08:56.030 --> 00:09:01.300
RC4 is implemented as a variable key size
cypher that is gonna be a stream cypher.

188
00:09:01.300 --> 00:09:05.700
Operates on those bits as they go by, so
just wanna make sure we're aware of that.

189
00:09:05.700 --> 00:09:11.240
RC5 is gonna have 128-bit
key size associated with it.

190
00:09:11.240 --> 00:09:14.700
It's what we call a parameterized
algorithm, it has a variable block size so

191
00:09:14.700 --> 00:09:17.800
it can operate on different
blocks at different sizes,

192
00:09:17.800 --> 00:09:19.720
with variable key sizes as well.

193
00:09:19.720 --> 00:09:20.885
And variable numbers of rounds.

194
00:09:20.885 --> 00:09:24.120
Think about having a bunch
of dials where you can just

195
00:09:24.120 --> 00:09:25.975

in all these things.

196
00:09:25.975 --> 00:09:29.700
RC5 is gonna be one of those that you
could just literally set what you want,

197
00:09:29.700 --> 00:09:32.370
and it kinda just operations
based on those combinations.

198
00:09:32.370 --> 00:09:36.310
So it's a very secure solution because
you have to get the exact combinations of

199
00:09:36.310 --> 00:09:38.400
things to understand how to wind it back.

200
00:09:38.400 --> 00:09:42.150
And then RC6 is a symmetric key
block cypher, so it's a private key,

201
00:09:42.150 --> 00:09:45.490
single key block cypher,
that is going to come from RC5.

202
00:09:45.490 --> 00:09:49.830
It's essentially derived from RC5
with two additional benefits.

203
00:09:49.830 --> 00:09:54.214
We use integer multiplication to
do some of the internal functions.

204
00:09:54.214 --> 00:09:56.830
And we use a 4-bit working register,

205
00:09:56.830 --> 00:10:00.640
whereas RC5 uses a 2-bit register
to do the internal working.

206
00:10:00.640 --> 00:10:03.179
So we double the size of
the register making it more secure.

207
00:10:03.179 --> 00:10:05.073
So it's like RC5 plus.

208
00:10:05.073 --> 00:10:06.240
>> If you want to think of it that way.

209
00:10:06.240 --> 00:10:07.949
>> [LAUGH] That's what RC6 is.

210
00:10:07.949 --> 00:10:10.681
And then we have what's known as the DSA,
Digital Signature Algorithm.

211
00:10:10.681 --> 00:10:12.305
The Digital Signature Algorithm.

212
00:10:15.015 --> 00:10:18.415
We've talked about digital signing before,
and digitally signing things.

This is going to be used
